attributes.text:
A finite state machine.

See {@link qx.util.fsm.State} for details on creating States, and {@link qx.util.fsm.Transition} for details on creating transitions between states.
The name of this finite state machine
Process all of the events on the event queue.

An event that has been dispatched. The event may be handled (if the current state handles this event type), queued (if the current state blocks this event type), or discarded (if the current state neither handles nor blocks this event type).
Run the finite state machine to process a single event.
Whether the event should be disposed. If it was blocked, we’ve pushed it back onto the event queue, and it should not be disposed.
If the explicit transitions does not exist.
If the transition returns an invalid value.
If the next step will transit to an nonexistent state.
If the state stack is empty and the next state is POP_STATE_STACK
If the next state is invalid.
The friendly name to used for access to the object being added.
The object to associate with the specified friendly name
An optional list of group names of which this object is a member.
Add an object (typically a widget) that is to be accessed during state transitions, to the finite state machine.
An object of class qx.util.fsm.State representing a state which is to be a part of this finite state machine.
Add a state to the finite state machine.
If the given state is not an instanceof of qx.util.fsm.State.
If the given state already exists.
Display all of the saved objects and their reverse mappings.
The event to be enqueued
If true, put the event at the head of the queue for immediate processing. If false, place the event at the tail of the queue so that it receives in-order processing.
Enqueue an event for processing
The event that was dispatched.
Event listener for all event types in the finite state machine
The type of event, e.g. “execute”
The target of the event

The data, if any, to issue in the event. If this parameter is null then a qx.event.type.Event is instantiated. Otherwise, an event of type qx.event.type.Data is instantiated and this data is applied to it.
Create an event and send it immediately to the finite state machine.

Returns the (computed) value of the property debugFlags.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #debugFlags}.
(Computed) value of debugFlags.
The object for which the friendly name is desired
Get the friendly name of an object.
If the object has been previously registered via {@link #addObject}, then the friendly name of the object is returned; otherwise, null.
The name of the group for which the member list is desired.
Retrieve the list of objects which have registered, via {@link #addObject} as being members of the specified group.
An array containing the friendly names of any objects which are members of the specified group. The resultant array may be empty.

Returns the (computed) value of the property maxSavedStates.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #maxSavedStates}.
(Computed) value of maxSavedStates.

Returns the (computed) value of the property name.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #name}.
(Computed) value of name.

Returns the (computed) value of the property nextState.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #nextState}.
(Computed) value of nextState.
The friendly name of the object to be retrieved.
Retrieve an object previously saved via {@link #addObject}, using its Friendly Name.
The object which has the specified friendly name, or undefined if no object has been associated with that name.

Returns the (computed) value of the property previousState.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #previousState}.
(Computed) value of previousState.

Returns the (computed) value of the property state.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #state}.
(Computed) value of state.
Initial value for property debugFlags.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property debugFlags with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #debugFlags}.
the default value
Initial value for property maxSavedStates.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property maxSavedStates with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #maxSavedStates}.
the default value
Initial value for property name.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property name with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #name}.
the default value
Initial value for property nextState.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property nextState with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #nextState}.
the default value
Initial value for property previousState.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property previousState with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #previousState}.
the default value
Initial value for property state.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property state with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #state}.
the default value
The event to add to the event queue for processing after state change.
Add the specified event to a list of events to be passed to the next state following state transition.

When true, then push the current state onto the stack. This might be used in a transition, before the state has changed. When false, then push the previous state onto the stack. This might be used in an on entry function to save the previous state to return to. If this parameter is a string, it is taken to be the name of the state to transition to.

Save the current or previous state on the saved-state stack. A future transition can then provide, as its nextState value, the class constant:

qx.util.fsm.FiniteStateMachine.StateChange.POP_STATE_STACK

which will cause the next state to be whatever is at the top of the saved-state stack, and remove that top element from the saved-state stack.
If the saved-state stack is full.
The friendly name associated with an object, specifying which object is to be removed.
Remove an object which had previously been added by {@link #addObject}.
An object of class qx.util.fsm.State representing a state which is to be a part of this finite state machine.
If true, then dispose the old state object. If false, the old state object is returned for disposing by the caller.

Replace a state in the finite state machine. This is useful if initially “dummy” states are created which load the real state table for a series of operations (and possibly also load the gui associated with the new states at the same time). Having portions of the finite state machine and their associated gui pages loaded at run time can help prevent long delays at application start-up time.
The old state object if it was not disposed; otherwise null.
If the given state is not an instanceof of qx.util.fsm.State.

Resets the user value of the property debugFlags.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #debugFlags}.

Resets the user value of the property maxSavedStates.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #maxSavedStates}.

Resets the user value of the property name.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #name}.

Resets the user value of the property nextState.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #nextState}.

Resets the user value of the property previousState.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #previousState}.

Resets the user value of the property state.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #state}.
The type of event, e.g. “execute”
The target of the event
See {@link #fireImmediateEvent} for details.
If provided, this is the number of milliseconds to wait before firing the event. If not provided, a default short interval (on the order of 20 milliseconds) is used.
Create and schedule an event to be sent to the finite state machine “shortly”. This allows such things as letting a progress cursor display prior to handling the event.
New value for property debugFlags.

Sets the user value of the property debugFlags.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #debugFlags}.
The unmodified incoming value.
New value for property maxSavedStates.

Sets the user value of the property maxSavedStates.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #maxSavedStates}.
The unmodified incoming value.
New value for property name.

Sets the user value of the property name.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #name}.
The unmodified incoming value.
New value for property nextState.

Sets the user value of the property nextState.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #nextState}.
The unmodified incoming value.
New value for property previousState.

Sets the user value of the property previousState.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #previousState}.
The unmodified incoming value.
New value for property state.

Sets the user value of the property state.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #state}.
The unmodified incoming value.
Start (or restart, after it has terminated) the finite state machine from the starting state. The starting state is defined as the first state added to the finite state machine.
If the machine stared with not available state.

Debug flags, composed of the bitmask values in the DebugFlags constant.

Set the debug flags from the application by or-ing together bits, akin to this:

var FSM = qx.util.fsm.FiniteStateMachine;
fsm.setDebugFlags(FSM.DebugFlags.EVENTS |
                  FSM.DebugFlags.TRANSITIONS |
                  FSM.DebugFlags.FUNCTION_DETAIL |
                  FSM.DebugFlags.OBJECT_NOT_FOUND);

The maximum number of states which may pushed onto the state-stack. It is generally a poor idea to have very many states saved on a stack. Following program logic becomes very difficult, and the code can be highly unmaintainable. The default should be more than adequate. You’ve been warned.
The name of this finite state machine (for debug messages)
The state to which we will be transitioning. This property is valid only during a Transition’s ontransition function and a State’s onexit function. At all other times, it is null.

The previous state of the finite state machine, i.e. the state from which we most recently transitioned. Note that this could be the same as the current state if a successful transition brought us back to the same state.
The current state of the finite state machine.
